boxed-text.title: Grants and Awards
boxed-text.p: The W. K. Kellogg Foundation supports opportunities to invest in early child development (ages 0-8), leading to reading proficiency by third grade, high school graduation, and pathways to meaningful employment. The Foundation’s recommended strategies include whole child development, family literacy, and educational advocacy. To be eligible for support, the organization or institution, as well as the purpose of the proposed project, must be a nonprofit. Grant amounts range from US$30,000 to US$255,000. The Kellogg Foundation does not have any submission deadlines. Grant applications are accepted throughout the year. For more information, visit the W. K. Kellogg Foundation at http://www.wkkf.org

The Davidson Institute for Talent Development recognizes a significant piece of work in science, technology, mathematics, music, literature, philosophy, or “outside the box.” The recognition is accompanied by a US$50,000, US$25,000, or US$10,000 scholarship. Eligible applicants must be high-achieving young people in the United States who are 18 or younger as of September 29, 2013, and are working on a graduate-level project. Applicants must submit an original piece of work recognized by experts in the field as significant that has the potential to make a positive contribution to society. The scholarship may be used at any accredited institute of learning. The deadline to apply is generally in February with notification occurring on or before July 15. For more information, visit the Davidson Institute for Talent Development at http://www.davidsongifted.org

The National Association for Gifted Children (NAGC) supports the 2013 Javits-Frasier Scholarship for Diverse Talent Development that recognizes passionate, innovative educators in communities across the country where students from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds are historically underrepresented in gifted programs. Eligible applicants must work in a Title I School, have not previously attended an NAGC Convention, have not received the award before, and must have only 1 to 2 years of experience in the field of gifted education. Award winners receive up to US$500 travel stipend (plus hotel) to attend the NAGC Annual Convention, complimentary registration to the Annual Convention, a teaching resource toolkit and link to an advisor, and a 2-year membership in NAGC. For more information about the award, visit NAGC at http://www.nagc.org/javitsfrasierscholars.aspx

The NAGC sponsors the Hollingworth Award to encourage educational and psychological research studies of potential benefit to gifted and talented children. The award is open to individuals, educational institutions, and other organizations that present proposals for publishable research projects. The applicant may be a professor, educational administrator, psychologist, teacher, graduate student, or other professional individual. The award consists of a cash grant, paid in two installments: first at the awards ceremony during NAGC’s Annual Convention and after receipt of the final report by the Chair of the Awards Committee. Deadline is May 1. For more information, visit NAGC at http://www.nagc.org/index.aspx?id=1120

The Spencer Foundation is concerned with advancing the learning and development of children and adults that lead to a better understanding and improvements in the intellectual, material, and organizational resources that contribute to successful teaching and learning. A key aim of research is to support investigations of questions that are grounded directly in teaching practice as well as in research about important aspects of teaching and learning processes that hold promise for enriching opportunities to learn and for guiding informed policy making. The Foundation is particularly interested in studies of teaching and teacher development—what teachers need to know and do to enable all students to learn. Eligible applicants include school districts, colleges or universities, research facilities, or cultural institutions. Principal investigators must have an earned doctorate in an education-related profession. Small grants are up to US$40,000 and major grants are US$40,001 to US$500,000. Deadlines for small grants are July 23, 2013; October 15, 2013; and February 11, 2014; and for large grants is February 5, 2014. For more information, visit the Spencer Foundation at http://www.spencer.org/content.cfm/teaching-learning-and-instructional-resources
The National Council for the Social Studies (NCSS) supports the following awards and grants:

list-item.p: An annual NCSS Outstanding Teacher of the Year Award that recognizes exceptional classroom social studies teachers for Grades K to 6, 5 to 8, and 7 to 12 who teach social studies regularly in elementary school and half-time in middle or junior high and high school settings. Award winners receive US$2,500, complimentary 1-year membership in NCSS, and present a session on their work at the NCSS Annual Conference, and up to US$500 in transportation/lodging reimbursement to attend the Annual Conference.

An award for Global Understanding in honor of James M. Becker that recognizes a social studies educator (or a team of educators) who has made notable contributions in helping social studies students increase their understanding of the world. Eligible applicants must be NCSS members and social studies educators of students in Grades P-12. Award winners receive US$2,000, present a session on their work at the NCSS Annual Conference, complimentary NCSS conference registration, and up to US$700 in transportation/lodging reimbursement to attend the Annual Conference.

The Christa McAuliffe Reach for the Stars Award that provides funds for teachers in developing and implementing imaginative, innovative, and illustrative social studies teaching strategies; and in supporting students’ implementation of innovative social studies, citizenship projects, field experiences, and community connections. Eligible applicants must be NCSS members and a full-time social studies teacher of K-12 students. Award winners receive US$2,500.

boxed-text.p: For more information and deadlines, visit the NCSS website at http://socialstudies.org/awards

ING U.S. provides Unsung Heroes awards that support educators in accredited K-12 public or private schools in the United States, who wish to implement creative, unique, and effective projects that improve student learning. All awards must be used to further the projects within the school or school system. Each of the 100 finalists will receive an award of US$2,000. Of the finalists, 3 will be selected for additional financial awards with first-place winners receiving US$25,000; second place receiving US$10,000; and third place receiving US$5,000. For more information, visit http://ing.us/about-ing/citizenship/childrens-education/ing-unsung-heroes

The Executive Office of the President and the President’s Commission on White House Fellowships offers fellowships each year starting in August. The purpose of the White House Fellows program is to provide gifted and highly motivated young Americans with firsthand experience in the process of governing the Nation and a sense of personal involvement in the leadership of society. White House Fellows typically spend a year as full-time, paid assistants to senior White House Staff, the Vice President, Cabinet Secretaries and other top-ranking government officials. Their assignments demand a capacity for quick learning and a willingness to work hard, often on issues outside of their area of expertise. Responsibilities range from chairing interagency meetings and designing and implementing federal policies to drafting speeches for cabinet secretaries to representing their agencies on Capitol Hill. Applicants must be U.S. citizens, have completed their undergraduate education, and be working in their chosen professions. With the fellowship comes a salary of approximately US$100,000 per year. Fellows also are eligible to purchase health insurance at their agencies. For more information about the Fellowship, including deadlines, visit The White House at http://www.whitehouse.gov/about/fellows/about

sec.title: Teen Ink Community Service Award
sec.p: Teen Ink is a national teen magazine that is widely distributed in English classrooms across the country. The publisher, Young Authors Foundation, seeks to promote the preservation of young people’s sense of self-worth by helping them share their own stories while developing reading, writing, creative, and creative-thinking skills. Teen Ink publishes poetry, essays, stories, reviews, art, and photography entries from teens in the magazine with their ongoing cover art, nonfiction, poetry, educator of the year, fiction, travel and culture, environment, and community service contests. For the community service contest, they honor at least two teens (between the ages of 13 and 19) each year for outstanding service to their community. Essay entries must be original and should be between 150 and 1,000 words. The essay can be about a moving experience about volunteering, someone special they met by volunteering, or describing their service and why it’s important. Photos are optional. The winner will receive US$100 for their favorite charity and a copy of the magazine featuring their winning essay. They will also be able to choose prizes from a selection of Teen Ink merchandise. Entries are accepted throughout the year. For more information, please visit http://www.teenink.com/Contests

sec.title: Mystery Build Art Contest
sec.p: Two artists created the Mystery Build Art Contest to inspire creative thinking because they believe every person has unlimited creative potential that can change lives and shape cultures. The purpose of the contest is to encourage artistic exploration and experimentation and to promote creativity and ingenuity. The Mystery Build Art Contest is about being resourceful and inventive. Entrants should exercise problem-solving skills to use materials in surprising ways, while creating a work of art and competing against other artists across the nation. To participate, participants should order a kit before September 30, 2013 (US$39 plus US$10 shipping). Using only the materials included in the kit, entrants should create a work of art using this year’s theme: “Re-Invent a Work of Art.” The entry should not be a replica of another work of art, but could be a reinterpretation, continuation, or unique version of the original artwork. Entries will be judged on the following criteria: creativity, relevance to the theme, and execution. In 2011, there was US$3,000 awarded in prize money and in 2012, there was US$11,800 awarded in prize money. In 2013, US$15,000 will be awarded to 21 winners. Participants may enter as individuals or as a team and need to be residents of the United States or Canada. The submission deadline of the photos or video of the art creation is due by October 10, 2013. For more information, please visit http://www.mysterybuild.com/

sec.title: Patriot’s Pen Essay Contest
sec.p: The Veterans of Foreign Wars exists to advocate on behalf of all veterans, promote patriotism, and serve communities. The Patriot’s Pen program is open to students in Grades 6 to 8 who are enrolled in a public, private, or parochial high school or home study program in the United States. More than 125,000 students participated in last year’s contest. Students should submit a 300- to 400-word essay relating to the theme “What Patriotism Means to Me.” Essays will be judged using the following criteria: (a) knowledge of the theme (worth 30 points), (b) theme development (worth 35 points), and (c) clarity of ideas (worth 35 points). The deadline for the 2013-2014 contest is November 1, 2013. Students should send in their essays along with the entry form to their local Veterans of Foreign Wars post. The first-place award is US$5,000 along with an all-expense paid trip to Washington, D.C. The top 46 national winners will receive at least US$500 each. Winning essays from previous contests are available on the contest website. For more information, please visit http://www.vfw.org/Community/Patriot-s-Pen/

sec.title: Creative Communication Contest
sec.p: Creative Communication is a company that exists to promote writing, teaching, and appreciation of student writing. The top entries of their students writing contests are published in an anthology to record creative insights of today’s student writers. Creative Communication’s essay contest is open to students in Grades 3 through 12 in the United States or Canada. Homeschooled students are welcome to enter. Students can submit a 100- to 250-word nonfiction essay on any appropriate subject. The essays are judged on literary merit, creativity, and social significance. The judges are published writers and/or educators in elementary, secondary, and higher education. For each contest deadline, the top 10 entries in each grade division (3-6, 7-9, 10-12) will receive a US$25 check, special recognition in a book, and a free copy of the anthology that will be created from the contest. Teachers with five or more students who give permission for publication will receive a free copy of the anthology that includes the essays of their students. Teachers also can qualify to apply for 1 of 50 US$250 grants awarded by Creative Communication each year. The top 10 winners will receive a free copy of the anthology. For the fall contest, entries must be postmarked by October 15, 2013. For more information, please visit http://www.poeticpower.com/essay.php
